label.label: Timor-Leste Ministry of Finance
label.involvement: Held the position of Minister of Finance, overseeing financial policies and economic development.
label.reasoning: Long-term leadership role in a national government ministry, indicating significant commitment and impact.

supporting_quotes: Emilia Pires was East Timor's Minister of Finance from April 2007 until 16 February 2015.
events.notes: Clear linkage between time, role, and location.

quotes: Emilia Pires was East Timor's Minister of Finance from April 2007 until 16 February 2015.
Ms. Pires was sworn in as the Minister of Finance of the V Constitutional Government of East Timor on August 8, 2012.

In July 2012, Pires was appointed by the Secretary-General of United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, to the 26-member High-level Panel of Eminent Persons advising the United Nations on the post 2015 global development agenda.
In 1975, as a teenager, Emilia Pires left East Timor (then Portuguese Timor) for Australia as a refugee, with her parents, brothers and sisters.
However, exile lasted for 24 years before Pires was able to return.

Díli, July 31, 2012 Emilia Pires appointed by the Secretary-General of United Nations Ban Ki-moon to High-level Panel of Eminent Persons on the post 2015 Development Agenda
Today the Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon announced the 26-member panel due to hold it’s first meeting in September.

With the target date for the Millennium Development Goals approaching in 2015, Ms. Pires will be contributing to shaping the post MDG agenda with “the fight against poverty and sustainable development at its core.”

label.label: g7+
label.involvement: Served as Chair of the g7+, a group of fragile and conflict-affected states.
label.reasoning: Leadership role in a significant international organization, reflecting long-term commitment to global development.

supporting_quotes: Since 2010 Ms Pires has been Chair of the g7+, championing the voice of conflict-affected and post conflict states.

As Chair, she has worked closely with the People of Timor-Leste as well as other Nations, civil society, the private sector and international partners to identify ways to improve development partnerships and accelerate aid effectiveness.

roles.title: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
quotes: The co-chairs of the High-level Panel of Eminent Persons are the President of the Republic of Indonesia, His Excellency Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, the President of the Republic of Liberia, Her Excellency Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf and the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, His Excellency David Cameron.

As Chair, she has worked closely with the People of Timor-Leste as well as other Nations, civil society, the private sector and international partners to identify ways to improve development partnerships and accelerate aid effectiveness.

The co-chairs of the High-level Panel of Eminent Persons are the President of the Republic of Indonesia, His Excellency Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, the President of the Republic of Liberia, Her Excellency Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf and the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, His Excellency David Cameron.

The co-chairs of the High-level Panel of Eminent Persons are the President of the Republic of Indonesia, His Excellency Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, the President of the Republic of Liberia, Her Excellency Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf and the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, His Excellency David Cameron.

The co-chairs of the High-level Panel of Eminent Persons are the President of the Republic of Indonesia, His Excellency Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, the President of the Republic of Liberia, Her Excellency Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf and the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, His Excellency David Cameron.

supporting_quotes: Forbes Magazine named her one of the world’s most powerful women in September 2009.

quotes:
Residency:
April 13–21, 2010

Public Talk:
April 19, 2010 on
Before Timor-Leste officially regained its independence in 2002, she lived and worked in Australia, commissioning tirelessly for human rights and independence on behalf of the people of Timor.
She spoke at the Congressional Hearing on the Humanitarian Crisis in East Timor in Washington, D.C., in September 1999.
She returned to Timor-Leste in 1999, offering her civil service experience to the National Council of Timorese Resistance and serving as director of the Department of Regional Services.
She took the position of secretary of the Commission on Planning in 2001,
and in 2007, she became Timor’s Finance Minister.
Forbes Magazine named her one of the world’s most powerful women in September 2009.

roles.title: Finance Minister
quotes: and in 2007, she became Timor’s Finance Minister.
Before Timor-Leste officially regained its independence in 2002, she lived and worked in Australia, commissioning tirelessly for human rights and independence on behalf of the people of Timor.
She spoke at the Congressional Hearing on the Humanitarian Crisis in East Timor in Washington, D.C., in September 1999.
She returned to Timor-Leste in 1999, offering her civil service experience to the National Council of Timorese Resistance and serving as director of the Department of Regional Services.
During her stay she also guest lectured in classes and met with students, leaders and members from the San Diego Southeast Asian community.
